body:
It's **not** a famous MNIST database of handwritten digits.
When people talk about MNIST database, they usually mean this:
http://yann.lecun.com/exdb/mnist/
 - it consists of **handwritten digits**
 - 28 x 28 images
 - 60 000 examples
 - 10 000 more examples (test data)

Your data:
 - digits, printed with **different fonts**
 - 71 x 77
 - ~5 000  examples
 - ~5 000 unlabeled

So, depending on your goals, you may start a new research on your data by evaluating different models, or you can use **"MNIST database of handwritten digits"** and try to reproduce the best performing models (like, `committee of 35 conv. net, 1-20-P-40-P-150-10 [elastic distortions]` whatever that means)

@gobzer Thank you. I'm new at this. Yes, this data sets is fonts not handwritten characters. I used a simple YAML and trained the font data over 20 hours at 10% accuracy. This example Python [code](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-build-a-neural-network-to-recognize-handwritten-digits-with-tensorflow) trained handwritten digits in a few minutes at 90+% accuracy. I guess more options in the YAML would help with Ludwig, I'm just not sure which options to use.

Here is the script that downloads original MNIST database and converts it to images and CSV:
https://gist.github.com/gobzer/dda71ee2e0be279050f87c6e75fb16c3
I was looking at the tensorflow tutorial https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials
and made this model:
**m2.yaml**
```
input_features:
    -
        name: path
        type: image
        encoder: stacked_cnn # default
        fc_size: 512 # default 256
        dropout: 0.2 # default false
        filter_size: 0 # default 3
        num_filters: 0 # default 256
        
output_features:
    -
        name: digit
        type: category

```
After 1 hour of training on CPU (1 epoch):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12876046/54994416-7f556d00-4fc4-11e9-8a7f-1d9700e17797.png)

The result is better, but it still not that 98%. And the training runs much slower.

@gobzer Thank you very much for taking the time to explain this to me. I need to study up quite a bit more on the fundamentals of ML and which knobs to turn for success. Ludwig removes the programming aspect of ML but does not remove the need to understand neural networks.
@DennisFaucher the truth is: **I have no idea what I did**

@gobzer I created a Google Colab so that others may benefit from your explanation: https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1XTvuc210e9sfiqzUDWUpn29xWwW-mOtg
Running it now...

Wow, thank you @gobzer for helping out! I'm changing the title as it is misleading.
Anyway, we were able to get 98%+ accuracy on mnist with just a little change to the default parameters. Can't recollect the exact ones, but if needed I can find them.

"Ludwig removes the programming aspect of ML but does not remove the need to understand neural networks." yeah that is true. You can easily train a model to decent accuracy in most cases, but to get something that works really well, you need to know what knobs to turn :)

I trained a new model. It performs better:

- orange - base
- blue - m2
- red - m3

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12876046/55077918-328f9600-5099-11e9-9c8f-db69d5fd9427.png)

I did this visualisation with:
`
tensorboard --logdir m1:experiment_run_0/model/log,m2:experiment_m2_1/model/log,m3:experiment_m3_0/model/log
`

### m3.yaml

```
# tinkering with MNIST model number 3 
input_features:
    -
        name: path
        type: image
        encoder: stacked_cnn # default
        fc_size: 512 # default 256
        dropout: 0.2 # default false
        filter_size: 0 # default 3
        num_filters: 0 # default 256
        
output_features:
    -
        name: digit
        type: category
        activation: softmax # default relu
        fc_size: 10 # default 256

```

But still. I feel like:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=12LLJFSBnS4
I started to read http://neuralnetworksanddeeplearning.com/ and it seems promising. But NN heavily relies on maths, and I'm having difficulties resolving these cognitive dependencies.

> if needed I can find them.

@w4nderlust I need them =)

But there is a thing I'm really concerned about. The tf/keras MNIST tutorial runs in minutes (300 000 steps), and ludwig trains one step in 11 or 12 seconds on the same machine. The performance difference is HUGE!!!
This is great. Thank you @gobzer. I'll try this today.

Sometimes these runs seem to differ from machine to machine. I just used your YAML in Google Colab and ended up with 11% accuracy. Colab: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1XTvuc210e9sfiqzUDWUpn29xWwW-mOtg YAML: input_features: - name: digit_image type: image encoder: stacked_cnn fc_size: 512 dropout: 0.2 output_features: - name: digit type: category training: epochs: 100 Results:

@DennisFaucher I checked your notebook and found a mistake.
You use test data for training.
`!cat /content/testing/data.csv | sed '2,$s/^\"/\"\/content\/testing\//' > data2.csv`
In `MNIST dataset` test data is a portion of training data. Ludwig automatically slices data into training/test/validation. So, within my experiments I don't use test data at all.

Here is my python notebook (90% accuracy).
https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1lekKocEQRq5Owon5CIoSB3lBY1EOur3C

I think that only **dropout** really matter. If you can improve it, leave a note.

UPDATE:
I also found that there is a [MNIST example in docs](https://uber.github.io/ludwig/examples/#image-classification-mnist). Here is the notebook that trains the model in the example (96% accuracy):
https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1V0Yb_-PWhExMnK7yA2_Pf-gNSEgnd9wE
